factoid: At the Olmütz review, the narrator seemed more majestic.
Here, the narrator seemed brighter and more energetic.
The narrator was slightly flushed after galloping two miles.
The narrator sighed restfully while reining in the narrator's horse.
The narrator looked around at the faces of his entourage, which were young and animated.
Czartorýski, Novosíltsev, Prince Volkónsky, Strógonov, and others were richly dressed young men on splendid, well-groomed, fresh, only slightly heated horses.
They were exchanging remarks and smiling.
They had stopped behind Emperor Francis.
Emperor Francis was a rosy, long-faced young man.
Emperor Francis sat very erect on his handsome black horse.
Emperor Francis looked around in a leisurely and preoccupied manner.
Emperor Francis beckoned to one of his white adjutants.
Emperor Francis asked a question.
Prince Andrew thought that Emperor Francis was most likely asking at what o'clock they started.
Prince Andrew watched his old acquaintance with a smile he could not repress.
Prince Andrew recalled his reception at Brünn.
The Emperor's suite contained young orderly officers of the Guard and line regiments from Russia and Austria.
Among the officers were grooms leading the Tsar's beautiful relay horses covered with embroidered cloths.
A whiff of youthfulness, energy, and confidence of success reached Kutúzov's staff with the arrival of the brilliant young men.
The arrival of the brilliant young men was described as a galloping advent.
Emperor Alexander asked Kutúzov, "Why aren't you beginning, Michael Ilariónovich?"
Emperor Alexander glanced courteously at Emperor Francis while speaking to Kutúzov.
Kutúzov answered, "I am waiting, Your Majesty," and bent forward respectfully.
Emperor Alexander frowning slightly bent his ear forward as if he had not quite heard.
Kutúzov repeated, "Waiting, Your Majesty."
Prince Andrew noted that Kutúzov's upper lip twitched unnaturally when he said "waiting."
Kutúzov said, "Not all the columns have formed up yet, Your Majesty."
The Tsar heard Kutúzov's reply but did not like it.
The Tsar shrugged his rather round shoulders.
The Tsar glanced at Novosíltsev, who was near him, as if complaining about Kutúzov.
The Tsar said, "You know, Michael Ilariónovich, we are not on the Empress' Field where a parade does not begin till all the troops are assembled."
The Tsar glanced at Emperor Francis again, as if inviting him to join or at least listen.
Emperor Francis continued to look around and did not listen.
Kutúzov said, "That is just why I do not begin, sire," in a resounding voice.
Kutúzov's face twitched again.
Kutúzov said, "That is just why I do not begin, sire, because we are not on parade and not on the Empress' Field," clearly and distinctly.
In the Emperor's suite, everyone exchanged rapid looks expressing dissatisfaction and reproach.
The glances implied, "Old though he may be, he should not speak like that."
The Tsar looked intently into Kutúzov's eye, waiting to hear if he would say anything more.
Kutúzov bowed his head respectfully and seemed to be waiting.
The silence lasted about a minute.
Kutúzov said, "However, if you command it, Your Majesty," lifting his head.
Kutúzov assumed his former tone of a dull, unreasoning, but submissive general.
Kutúzov touched his horse.
Kutúzov called Milorádovich, the commander of the column.
Kutúzov gave Milorádovich the order to advance.
The troops again began to move.
Two battalions of the Nóvgorod regiment moved forward past the Emperor.
One battalion of the Ápsheron regiment moved forward past the Emperor.
The red-faced Milorádovich was without his greatcoat.
Milorádovich had his Orders on his breast.
Milorádovich had an enormous tuft of plumes in his cocked hat worn on one side.
Milorádovich galloped strenuously forward as the Ápsheron battalion marched by.
Milorádovich gave a dashing salute and reined in his horse before the Emperor.
The Emperor said, "God be with you, general!"
The general answered gaily, "Ma foi, sire, nous ferons ce qui sera dans notre possibilité, sire."
The general's answer raised ironic smiles among the gentlemen of the Tsar's suite.
The general spoke in poor French.
The general said, "Indeed, Sire, we shall do everything it is possible to do, Sire."
